subtitle: Space practice across time > mass practice all at once
questions:
When do players get opportunities to practice skills in your game?
How often do you want your player to practice key skills?
How many times will they be exposed to each key skill?
How much time is between the initial learning and the final “test” or implementation of knowledge?
How much time will it require for players to complete practicing?
What is the minimum required time for one set of practice?
description:
Leave some time in between practice/study/play sessions. 
Delayed reexposure/review can be very effective in learning new material. It is more damaging not to have a review at all than it is to have too much space between the initial exposure and the review.
examples:
Studying for 1 hour a day for 12 days > Cramming for a test for 12 hours the day before
Playing Duolingo for 7 hours on the plane on the way to Japan < Playing for 20 minutes every day for 2 weeks
Give students a review of course material the day after it is first presented < Review several weeks later
exampleGameDesc: Duolingo is a mobile app for learning languages. Duolingo encourages users to take a break in between lessons by providing incentives for “streaks” of practicing for multiple days in a row.

subtitle: Sequence instruction toward higher goals > no sequencing
questions:
What are all the skills in your game?
What order does the player encounter them in?
Could the sequence be adjusted to introduce more complex skills later?
How can the different levels of skills be presented to the players?
How can bigger practices be broken down into smaller pieces?
description: Structure content modularly; build upon prior concepts when introducing new concepts, and build towards a higher goal.
examples:
Learn to draw contours and break objects down into shapes > draw a human figure in high fidelity
Teach a player to do a double-jump backflip in level 1 < teach jump in level 1,  doublejump in level 2, backflip in level 3, and double-jump backflip in level 4
exampleGameDesc: Minecraft is a popular open-ended game in which players explore the iconic, randomly generated, blocky terrain and break down resource blocks in order to combine them to build new things. Minecraft’s advancements tree is structured in a way that it serves as a walk-through of what to do next. Previous achievements make further achievements possible, often by producing resources needed to build further items.

subtitle: Students expect to be tested > no testing expected
questions:
What does the player need to know to succeed in your game?
Does the player feel that those KCs are necessary?
Can you make them feel more necessary?
How can players’ understanding be measured through the test?
description: Make it clear how key concepts being learned will be put to use later.
examples:
Tell your 6th grade class that there will be a quiz on this reading > tell them to do the reading because it will better them as a student
When teaching a player to perform a function, provide some examples of future tasks that this skill is needed to complete (“double jump: used for collecting butterflies”) > teach the function in a vacuum
exampleGameDesc: FreeCodeCamp is a free website that teaches users web development skills through a gamified curriculum of short “learn by doing” exercises. Each lesson begins with a few paragraphs of explanatory text and visuals, followed immediately by a coding problem. The user cannot complete the lesson without solving the problem. The consistent use of this pattern perpetuates the expectation that the information being learned in the introductory text is important, and will be put to use (tested on).

subtitle: Quiz for retrieval practice > study same material
questions:
Where do players exercise the skills they are learning in your game?
Do they have to exercise those skills repeatedly?
What are the core skills that must be tested before proceeding?
description: Re-expose players to core concepts by forcing them to recall material. Or pre-expose them to material they haven’t learned yet by asking them to make hypotheses about it.
examples:
Give a test summarizing the material > spend additional time studying the same material
Give a “pre-quiz” to expose students to upcoming math concepts and gauge progress > jump straight in
exampleGameDesc: Battleship Numberline is one of many K-12 math games that takes an approach of repetitive drilling (or quizzing) to ingrain concepts in the player’s mind. Time pressure and a display of average accuracy put some heat on the player.

subtitle: Present lesson in learner-paced segments > as a continuous unit
questions:
What are all of the skills that a player needs to succeed in your game?
What are additional skills that a player needs to successfully apply those skills?
What are additional skills that a player needs to successfully apply THOSE skills?
How will the game adjust to players with different learning paces?
description:
Break material down into units in order to allow the player/learner to approach the material at their own pace.
Math is not a skill, it is actually a collection of related skills that people can have different mastery of.
examples:
Levels > One very long game
A Portuguese lesson on verbs used in cooking > a very long, continuous curriculum on all Portuguese verbs

subtitle: Provide feedback during learning > no feedback provided
questions:
What are all the channels the game is using to communicate status to the player?
How many of these relate to their application of target concepts?
How does a player know how they are doing?
What are some actions players can take after receiving a feedback?
How often should the feedback be provided?
description:
Provide feedback to the player on their performance as they are learning.
Timing of feedback may differ depending on the task being performed. Immediate feedback during play can be valuable to encourage or discourage behavior.
examples: A child does a calculation incorrectly, but the teacher lets it go because it is a difficult problem < the teacher points out the mistake as it happens
exampleGameDesc: JobPro: Get Dressed! Is a mobile game created by Simcoach Games that trains players in how to dress for a job interview. Players choose an outfit based on the role they are interviewing for, the atmosphere of the company, and various other factors. After the player makes their selection they receive detailed feedback about the outfit they chose and its compatibility with the position.

subtitle: Practice key prior skills before lesson > jump in
questions:
What prior skills are required for this specific lesson?
How can these prior skills be practiced effectively before the lesson? Multiple short practices or one long practice?
How well should the players be trained in those prior skills?
description: Provide some exposure to key concepts before the actual lesson.
examples:
Assign some readings before the lecture > jump straight in
Start choir with a warm-up that is in the same style as the song they group will learn that day 
Make players practice writing one sentence at a time before making them write a paragraph
exampleGameDesc: Coding for Carrots is a drag-and-drop coding game that tells a story of a rabbit searches for carrots by completing the block building activity. There is a trial round before every official game. It offers pretraining of the skills that the game wants to test, and it also helps to set an expectation of the difficulty level for the players.

subtitle: Worked examples + problem-solving practice > practice alone
questions:
How many or what type of worked examples can be provided for this lesson?
How can we make sure that players aren’t simply cloning the worked examples instead of solving the practices?
description:
Combine problem-solving practice with reviewing examples of solved problems that illustrate the steps taken to reach a solution.
Having students alternate between reviewing worked examples and solving similar problems on their own has been shown to be effective when teaching math, science, and technology.
examples:
A computer science student reviews code from a few similar projects while determining what approach she will take to do her homework assignment > she looks at the assignment and thinks about it really hard
An algebra textbook provides a worked example for each type of practice problem, using different variables and values > descriptive text and practice problems only
exampleGameDesc:
Anti-Phishing Phil is a game that teaches users how to identify phishing URLs, where to look for cues in web browsers, and how to use search engines to find legitimate sites. Each module of the game begins with a non-interactive tutorial in which the player is presented with several worked examples of the types of problems they will need to solve.

Anti-Phishing Phil was developed by members of the Carnegie Mellon University Usable Privacy and Security Laboratory with funding from the US National Science Foundation (Cyber Trust initiative) and ARO/CyLab.

subtitle: Concrete to abstract representations > starting with abstract
questions:
What are some concrete/abstract representations of the concept?
What is the target audience and how will this affect the choice of concrete representations?
How are some ways of bridging the concrete and abstract representations?
description:
When explaining key concepts, use both abstract and concrete representations. Draw connections between the abstract and concrete examples, and highlight how they represent the same critical takeaways.
Concrete representations can be effective for inciting initial understanding of a concept, but may not support transferring that knowledge to other concepts. Abstract representations may be more difficult to grasp initially, but have shown to foster the ability to put the same knowledge to use in very different domains. Therefore some experts recommend concreteness fading: introduce a concept with concrete examples, and over time replace key components of that example with more abstract representations.
examples:
“Shelly needs 3 dozen eggs. X = the number of eggs she needs.” > “X = 3(12). “
Review a diagram of the circle of 5ths < Play through it on piano while following along on the diagram
Chocolate bar split into 4 equal pieces > ¼

subtitle: Words include cues about organization > no organization cues
questions:
What are some segments of the lesson or practice that could be ambiguous to players?
What are some ways of explicitly stating the requirements?
How do we provide explicit instructions while keeping the players engaged? How can we give cues that won’t make the practices too easy or boring?
description:
Provide explicit instructions as needed to help the player anticipate where they should focus their attention.
 Verbal cues may accompany visuals to describe unfamiliar objects, or explain unobvious processes. Each text description should be near the visual element it describes.
examples:
A game with a tutorial and instructions > no text
A diagram illustrating the branches of government, with terms the player has never heard before < descriptive text throughout the graphic explains how they connect
exampleGameDesc:
Creature Capture is a strategy game published by the University of Washington Center for Game Science. It teaches young children to compare their game fraction values with those of the computer-controlled virals. 
To win the game, the player needs to pick a number that meets the requirement of the presented game cue.

subtitle: Integrate instructional components > no integration
description: Highlight connections between instructional units. Explicitly call out connections, similarities, and differences between previously learned and new material.
examples: Teach philosophy by giving an overview of each major philosopher < make connections between philosophers and how their beliefs about key topics compare and contrast

subtitle: Instruct at intermediate difficulty level > too hard or too easy
questions:
Who is your target player? 
How much prior exposure do they have to this material?
How could you make the material harder? Easier?
What is the goal of the game?
description: Account for the player’s prior knowledge and skill level when considering how challenging to make your game.
examples:
Students find a chemistry game completely unapproachable because it involves math far above their grade level < grade-level appropriate
CMU students taking a Java class already have a lot of Python experience that translates, and find the class too easy < appropriate curriculum

subtitle: Cue student's prior knowledge > no prior knowledge cues
questions:
What kinds of prior knowledge are required for this practice?
What are some links between the prior knowledge and the new concepts?
description:
Prompt players to examine what they already know (or think they know) to help contextualize new material.
Building upon what your player already knows and/or is interested in can make the game accessible and engaging.
examples: When explaining photosynthesis to a child, use a metaphor of how a person drinks milk through a straw like how a plant drinks water through its stem
exampleGameDesc: A Slower Speed of Light is a first-person game prototype developed by MIT Game Lab. A Slower Speed of Light is designed to build upon and challenge the average person’s understanding of how light travels. It begins with a very familiar experience: walking through a space at a human-like pace collecting objects. Picking up orbs reduces the speed of light in increments, triggering scientifically accurate visual effects.

subtitle: Immediate feedback on errors > delayed feedback
questions:
When players make mistakes, how do they know they’ve done so? When do you tell them? How long can a player go before realizing they need to turn back?
How can the feedback be provided? Visual? Auditory?
How can the players respond to the feedback? Are the errors immediately fixable? Or does it take more time to fix the error?
description: Provide immediate feedback on errors.
examples:
A musician plays a wrong note on guitar and hears the dissonance > a musician makes a mistake writing sheet music and later notices when playing through the line
A child touches a hot skillet and burns her hand > a child knocks over a vase and is later scolded
In the game “Operation,” they buzzer sounds immediately when the player touches the metal rim with the tool > a game that subtracts points each time the player makes a mistake and shows them their score at the end of the level
 A computer science student presses the “compile” button, and gets an error message < the moment the student makes a typo that line turns red
exampleGameDesc: Operation is a classic board game in which players perform “surgery” on a doll-shaped board, carefully extracting plastic objects from the body with a goal of not touching the board. If the player slips up and makes contact with the board a buzzer sounds immediately.

subtitle: Intermix practice on different skills > block practice all at once
questions:
What are different types of skills to be practiced?
How can the game easily transition from one topic to another?
How can some practices be combined to create an interdisciplinary practice?
description: Practice different skills at the same time, or in alternation.
examples:
A math homework assignment that requires 3 hours of long division < an assignment that includes a variety of types of practice problems
A dance teacher choreographs a piece combining different techniques that the class has learned this month for them to practice > Additional practice of the same techniques
Cindy decides to write a poem for her French assignment to practice writing poetry and also French
A yoga class mixes both yin and yang practices > long holds only
 When studying for a standardized test - good to alternate between different sections (Reading, Writing, and Math) in varying orders; bad to focus on fully studying one section, moving on to fully study the next section, and so on.
exampleGameDesc: Ninja Kitchen is a restaurant serving game focusing on food safety. The player role plays a ninja server, and he/she learns to operate the restaurant through a mixture of smaller games targeting different perspectives, including dish washing, food preparing, serving, etc. The harder the game goes, the busier the restaurant runs. The players will practice all kinds of skills in later levels.

subtitle: Practice applying new knowledge > no application
questions:
How much practice will it take for your player to understand the material?
What are the components that are most important to remember?
Does your game offer enough practice of key skills?
description: Challenge the player to put their newly acquired knowledge to use solving problems.
examples:
Practice playing newly learned chords on guitar > study additional new chord shapes
Provide a tutorial round that forces the player to work through how to control their character
exampleGameDesc: Players learn by doing in Crayon Physics Deluxe,  a 2D physics puzzle / sandbox game. Players draw their own solution to manipulate a ball to make contact with a star, and watch as their drawings come alive and obey the laws of physics.

subtitle: Practice with varied instances > similar instances
questions:
Are you encouraging thinking about this concept from different perspectives?
Will your player be able to transfer the knowledge they acquire to other domains?
description: No two situations are ever exactly the same, so you should prepare your players to apply their knowledge in all the varied situations of life. Use multiple and varied examples to teach and practice the use of abstract concepts.
examples:
Use only examples of classical music to illustrate a music theory concept < highlight the same pattern in classical, pop, and jazz music
A parent explains a complex concept to a child using a single metaphor, and the child interprets the metaphor literally < multiple metaphors and/or concrete examples used

subtitle: Compare multiple instances > only one instance
questions:
What are some commonalities across all variables of instances?
How can the game encourage players to find similarities/differences?
description: Use multiple examples to explain a new concept, and highlight similarities and differences between the examples.
examples: Use only examples of classical music to illustrate a music theory concept < highlight the same pattern in classical, pop, and jazz music

subtitle: Graphics + verbal descriptions > verbal descriptions alone
related: modality, redundancy, spatial contiguity, temporal contiguity
questions:
How can this particular description presented in a different way using graphics?
What are some graphics that can improve player experience?
What are some graphics that can help organize the content presented?
description: Use visual aids to enhance verbal descriptions.
examples:
A visualization of median income by state > A list alone
A labeled map accompanying a description of Egyptian trade routes > description alone
A picture of a cute dog above a passage about removing ticks from animals < an illustration demonstrating proper tick removal technique

subtitle: Verbal descriptions presented in audio > in written form
related: multimedia, redundancy, spatial contiguity, temporal contiguity
questions:
What descriptions can or cannot be fully presented in audio?
How quickly should the descriptions presented in audio?
description:
Present verbal descriptions in audio rather than text when possible.
Players may find their attention divided when presented with written text and competing visuals simultaneously.
examples:
A safety training course with spoken narration > written instructions
Watching a documentary on mute with subtitles < sound
exampleGameDesc:
Civilization is a turn-based strategy game (and/or resource management game) in which the player builds a civilization from scratch, starting in the Ancient Era.
Civ frequents the modality principle; for key events, a character will read the text aloud while a graphic is shown. The voice that reads the information is typically anchored in reality by being linked to a character and scenario, either the advisor (a character who guides the player through the rules of Civ) or an explorer.

subtitle: Verbal descriptions in audio > both audio & written
related: multimedia, modality, spatial contiguity, temporal contiguity
questions:
What descriptions can or cannot be fully presented in audio?
Should the verbal descriptions be completely or partially removed?
description: If you are able to provide verbal descriptions in audio, refrain from also including those same instructions in written form.
examples:
Watching a documentary with sound and subtitles < sound
Apple Keynotes slides are famously simple, with a single image or a logo, and without any written descriptions. Meanwhile, the presenter delivers everything verbally.

subtitle: Present description next to image element described > separated
questions:
What are some presented images that require verbal descriptions?
How can we format/place the description relative the image?
What is the purpose of the description for the image? Is it purely informational or does it have other purposes?
description: Position descriptive text as closely as possible to the part of the visualization it describes.
examples:
A reader has to flip forward several pages to find diagram 1.7 < diagram is located inline with the text it supports
Tooltips are used to provide more information on elements of a data visualization

subtitle: Present audio & image element at the same time > separated
questions:
What are the audio & image elements required for this practice?
Which audio elements are related to which image elements?
description: Present complementary audio and visual elements at the same time to encourage the player to form a connection between the two stimuli.
examples:
Show photographs from the great depression while lecturing > photographs reviewed later
A music teacher shows photos of instruments while describing them < view photographs of instruments while listening to the sounds each one makes
Ted Talks - speaker speaks as related graphics are displayed on the big screen behind them.

subtitle: Extraneous words, pictures, sounds excluded > included
questions:
What are your player's purposes?
How do those purposes support your learning goal?
What are some words, pictures, or sounds that are essential for the practice?
How can we combine or summarize some information to convey the same information in a simpler way?
When do the players feel like there’s “too much” information?
description: Refrain from including extraneous words, pictures, and sounds that do not serve the purpose of your game.
examples:
A powerpoint includes lots of decorative illustrations that students pay more attention to than the actual lesson < purposeful words and images only
A game features a lot of distracting sound effects < sounds used selectively to provide immediate feedback on actions and enhance the experience
exampleGameDesc: Septris is an educational tool created by Stanford Hospital to train medical and surgical staff to diagnose, classify, and treat sepsis according to best practices. The Septris user-interface is sparse, mimicking a patient’s medical chart. The player faces the challenge of parsing a lot of information without any extraneous graphics or imagery.

subtitle: Real-world problems > abstract problems
related: Concreteness fading/ concrete grounding, worked example
questions:
What is the real-world connection?
How does the player’s in-game progress impact their real-world life?
How is what the player does in your game like what they would do in real life? How is it different?
What are some real life applications of the skills being practiced?
How can players relate the new skills learned in their own lives?
description: Engage the player in realistic rather than theoretical problem-solving, and emphasize the connections between the game and the real world.
examples:
Instruct middle schoolers in an economics course to build a hypothetical portfolio of stocks and watch those stocks over the course of the semester > study fictional problems of market fluctuation
A student project of building a double transducer < building an assistive device for a real person
exampleGameDesc: Lift Coach is a game that educates people to use safe postures to lift and move objects. Players can correct how on-screen character lifts objects, and the goal is to avoid unsafe actions might lead to injuries. Lifting is such a common daily activity, but not many have paid attention to it. By referring back to real life cases, people will have an easier time to understand the mechanism behind and how to protect themselves in real hard-lifting scenarios.

subtitle: Metacognition supported > no support for metacognition
questions:
How should players be different after playing your game?
How will your player measure your game’s impact?
What are your player’s strengths and weaknesses?  How can they see them?
What parts of the game are particularly effective or relevant to your player personally?
description: Engage the player in their own learning experience. Empower them to self-reflect and self-correct.
examples:
An elearning course gives the same test at the beginning and end to show the student their progress
A time-management app encourages the user to set custom goals and reflect upon their progress on a weekly basis
A programming tutorial gives near-immediate feedback on errors in the beginning, and gradually transitions into more delayed feedback to allow the student to recognize and troubleshoot their own mistakes
Math problem - good to have students write down each step of the solution and reasoning behind it; bad to have students just write down the final answer.
exampleGameDesc: Survival of the Best Fit is a short game designed to teach people to understand algorithmic bias, and prompt them to ask tough questions about their own biases. The game features a series of short segments with periodic breaks to reflect on what just happened and why they made the decisions they made.

subtitle: Prompt for self-explanation > give explanation > no prompt
questions:
What are the causal relationships between the concepts being explored?
When are players making decisions regarding their learning that require independent thinking?
When are players given chances to self-explain?
What type of feedback can be provided after they have self-explained?
description:
Prompt the player to reason through the underlying explanatory principles relating to the subject matter being explored.
Encourage the player to reflect upon their own problem-solving process and challenge, explain, and defend their choices.
examples: Have a student show their work on an algebra problem > show a worked problem > show solution only
exampleGameDesc: SET is a cognitive, logical reasoning game. A SET is three cards which share a common feature, such as color or shape. The player who finds the most SETs within the timeframe wins the game. Since every player has his/her own understanding of how to make up the SET, each will prompt to explain their thoughts and definition.

subtitle: Time for reflection & questioning > instruction alone
questions:
Does the game provide opportunities to reflect?
Has the player acquired sufficient subject knowledge to ask deep questions?
In what ways could a player check their understanding through the game?
What are some ways of motivating the players to question things?
What type of questions will be effective for stimulating critical thinking?
description: Empower your player to embrace and explore uncertainties they encounter. Encourage the player to take time to reflect and ask deep questions; questions that stimulate deep explanations, and may challenge their prior beliefs and assumptions.
examples:
What is the correct data type to use for a single character? < What is data? What isn’t data?
What year did the American Revolutionary War end? < What might the world look like today if the war had ended differently?

subtitle: Present incorrect or alternative perspective > only correct
questions:
How objective or subjective is the material being taught?
How many ways are there to approach the challenges in your game? How many are players likely to encounter themselves?
How can  the player recognize mistakes or misuse of the material?
description: Present incorrect or alternative perspectives of the subject matter to afford the player the opportunity to form arguments around key concepts.
examples: Show an example of a common misconception and explain why it is false > correct examples only

subtitle: Instruction relevant to student interests > not relevant
questions:
Who is your target player? What motivates them?
Does your player have a personal stake in their transformation?
What is the ecosystem in which your game must create change?
description: Engage your player by structuring content around their interests and goals.
examples: Allow guitar students to choose their own songs to learn < forced set of songs
